com.milk.util
Interface Table

All Known Implementing Classes:
FlatTable
public interface Table

A Table is a mapping from keys to values. How keys are checked for equality is generally up to the particular kind of Table.

Author:
Dan Bornstein, danfuzz@milk.com
, Copyright 1999 Dan Bornstein, all rights reserved.

Method Summary
 boolean containsKey(java.lang.Object key)
          Return true if the given key is in the table.
 java.util.Enumeration elements()
          Get an Enumeration of all the elements of the table.
 java.lang.Object get(java.lang.Object key, java.lang.Object notFound)
          Get the value for the given key, or return the given notFound value if there is no such key.
 TableElement getElement(java.lang.Object key)
          Get a key-value mapping object indicating the actual mapping stored in the table, or return null if there is no such key.

          Return the comparator which is used to test keys for equality.

          Return the predicate which is used to test keys for validity.
 ObjectPredicate getValuePredicate()
          Return the predicate which is used to test values for validity.
 boolean isEmpty()
          Return true if this table is empty.
 boolean put(java.lang.Object key, java.lang.Object value)
          Map a key to a value.
 boolean remove(java.lang.Object key)
          Remove a key (and associated value) from the table.
 int size()
          Get the size of the table, that is, the number of key-value mappings the table contains.
 

Method Detail

getKeyPredicate

public ObjectPredicate getKeyPredicate()
Return the predicate which is used to test keys for validity. If the key predicate returns true for a particular object, then it is okay to use that object as a key in this table.

Returns:
the key predicate

getValuePredicate

public ObjectPredicate getValuePredicate()
Return the predicate which is used to test values for validity. If the value predicate returns true for a particular object, then it is okay to use that object as a value in this table.

Returns:
the key predicate

getKeyComparator

public Comparator getKeyComparator()
Return the comparator which is used to test keys for equality. Note that, when asked to compare two keys and one is already in the table, the one in the table is always the first argument to Comparator.compareEquals().

Returns:
the key comparator

size

public int size()
Get the size of the table, that is, the number of key-value mappings the table contains.

Returns:
the size of the table

isEmpty

public boolean isEmpty()
Return true if this table is empty. This is generally equivalent to size() == 0.

Returns:
true if the table is empty

containsKey

public boolean containsKey(java.lang.Object key)
Return true if the given key is in the table.

Parameters:
key - the key
Returns:
true if the key is in the table

get

public java.lang.Object get(java.lang.Object key,
                            java.lang.Object notFound)
Get the value for the given key, or return the given notFound value if there is no such key.

Parameters:
key - the key to look up
notFound - the value to return if the key isn't found
Returns:
either the value associated with the key or the notFound value if there is no such key

getElement

public TableElement getElement(java.lang.Object key)
Get a key-value mapping object indicating the actual mapping stored in the table, or return null if there is no such key. The key embodied in the returned TableElement may be different from the given one because a table may use an operation other than == to test for key equality.

Parameters:
key - the key to look up
Returns:
null-ok; either the key-value mapping or null if there is no such key

elements

public java.util.Enumeration elements()
Get an Enumeration of all the elements of the table. The enumeration consists only of TableElement objects. Note that, although some particular tables may allow it, it is generally a bad idea to modify a table while actively enumerating it.

Returns:
the enumeration

put

public boolean put(java.lang.Object key,
                   java.lang.Object value)
Map a key to a value. If the key already mapped to a value, then replace that mapping.

Parameters:
key - the key
value - the value
Returns:
true if the key was found and replaced, false if the operation put a new binding in the table

remove

public boolean remove(java.lang.Object key)
Remove a key (and associated value) from the table. If the key wasn't in the table, this doesn't affect the table.

Parameters:
key - the key to remove
Returns:
true if the key was found and removed, false if the key wasn't in the table
